nodes.text: Counties causally affect children's adult incomes; estimating county-level causal exposure effects identifies which places produce better intergenerational mobility and can guide policy and family moves

Method: Identify county causal exposure effects using a movers fixed-effects regression that exploits families who move across counties/CZs at different child ages and regress child outcome on county-by-exposure-year indicators with origin-by-destination fixed effects
Data: Deidentified federal tax records for all children born 1980–1986, locations from ZIPs on returns/W-2s; outcomes measured as household income rank at age 26 (primary) and other outcomes

Assumption: Conditional on origin-by-destination fixed effects, a child's exposure time to each place is orthogonal to other determinants of outcomes (no age-dependent selection into timing of moves to a given county)

Validation evidence: placebo tests and controls (controls for pre/post-move parental income and marital status; placebo using movers after exposure is irrelevant and teenage labor force participation) show movers-based estimates are uncorrelated with these placebo estimates, supporting identification

Result (magnitude): For children from low-income families (parents at 25th percentile), each additional year of childhood exposure to a one standard deviation better county increases adult household income ~0.5% (≈0.17 percentile points per year); 20 years from birth ≈10% income gain

Result (heterogeneity): Substantial variation in causal effects across counties (signal SD ≈0.17 percentile-years) including large within-metro differences; counties within same CZ can differ meaningfully (e.g., Manhattan vs Hudson County)

Result (subgroups): Neighborhood causal effects matter more for boys than girls (signal SD ≈60% larger for boys in low-income families); boys have a thicker lower tail with especially negative outcomes in high-poverty segregated areas

Method (forecasting): Construct MSE-minimizing forecasts of county causal effects by optimally shrinking movers' unbiased but noisy fixed-effect estimates toward predictions from outcomes of permanent residents (nonmovers) using estimated signal and noise variances

Result (forecasts & examples): Shrinkage forecasts produce precise guidance for families; among large counties DuPage County, IL ranks highest for low-income children (≈0.80% per year; ≈16% from birth), while Cook County ranks among worst (≈−13% from birth)

Claim (predictors): Areas that causally produce better outcomes for low-income children tend to have less concentrated poverty and segregation, lower income inequality (including top 1% share), better school outcomes, higher share of two-parent families, and lower crime; many of these correlations are driven primarily by causal place effects rather than selection

Claim (housing/rents and opportunity bargains): Areas that generate better outcomes tend to have higher house prices on average, but within CZs rents explain little of variance in causal effects (<5% in many cases) so many 'opportunity bargains' exist—places that yield good child outcomes without substantially higher rents; this may reflect information frictions and other factors

Limitation and caveat: Identification relies on a stronger orthogonality condition (one per county) than prior average exposure work; estimates assume additive, age-constant place effects and equal effects across movers and permanent residents conditional on parent income—heterogeneous or age-varying effects could alter interpretation

Conclusion and policy implication: Results support place-focused interventions (helping families move to high-opportunity places and place-based investments) and use of movers-based causal estimates to guide policy; further work needed to estimate effects at finer geographies and to identify mechanisms for causal factors (e.g., segregation, school quality)
